title: Republic of North Macedonia - Conflict Data

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 5 February 2021, about hundred residents of a nearby village protested on the Tetovo-Gostivar highway near Tetovo, demanding lower toll charges for them. [size=about hundred]

On 4 February 2021, administrative and technical staff protested outside the 8 September hospital in Skopje-Karpos, demanding the payment of a one-time financial assistance of 30,000 denars that was received only by the medical staff. [size=no report]

On 3 February 2021, hundreds of people protested in Skopje-Centar against the recent case of nonconsensual distribution of explicit photographs of women and girls in a private messaging group on Telegram. [size=hundreds]

On 29 January 2021, hundreds of Albanians protested today outside of the Primary Public Prosecutor's Office in Skopje-Centar, demonstrating their support for the defendants in the 'Monster' case. [size=hundreds]
On 28 January 2021, high school students protested outside of the Ministry of Education in Skopje-Centar, demanding changes to the state graduation exam. [size=no report]

On 27 January 2021, residents of the village protested in Kamen Dol, demanding protection against the dust from the nearby stone quarry, as well as better maintenance of the local roads. [size=no report]
On 26 January 2021, doctors from the 8 September Hospital protested in Skopje-Karpos, demanding their promised salary raises. [size=no report]
On 26 January 2021, accountants protested outside of the government headquarters in Skopje-Centar, demanding the extension of the deadlines for tax and financial reports. [size=no report]

On Nov. 20, 2018: Citizens gathered outside the Assembly in Skopje calling for an end to the constitutional amendments, arising from the name agreement with Greece.

On Nov. 18, 2018: A few thousand citizens gathered protested in Skopje calling for an end to the constitutional amendments, arising from the name agreement with Greece. The protesters gathered in front of Parliament and called for snap elections.
On Nov. 17, 2018: Citizens from Kumanovo protested against the bad air quality, demanding long-term measures to fight air pollution.
On Nov. 16, 2018: Citizens protested outside government building in Skopje seeking former PM Gruevski's extradition, interior minister's resignation, and former secret police head's detention.
Health Workers (North Macedonia); Labour Group (North Macedonia)
On Nov. 16, 2018: Physicians and nurses from private hospitals protested in Kocani expressing their discontent at the changes in their work conditions.
On Nov. 14, 2018: Taxi drivers blocked streets in Kocani protesting against the slow decision-making regarding illegal taxis.
On Nov. 12, 2018: Parents of students from a middle school in Stip protested blocking a road expressing discontent that their children are not safe enough at school.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On Nov. 7, 2018: Members of the opposition VMRO-DPMNE staged a protest in front of the Skopje court against the prison sentence of ex-Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski, insisting that he was a victim of politically-motivated prosecution.
On Nov. 6, 2018: Employees from OHIS protested in front of the Government of Macedonia demanding to be paid their outstanding salaries for 24 months.

On Nov. 4, 2018: Citizens marched and biked from Government to Parliament in Skopje protesting for the protection of animal rights. Activists alerted about frequent inhuman treatment of animals and demanded high penalties for unregistered and abandoned pets.

On Nov. 2, 2018: Residents from Skopje Aerodrom gathered to protest against the construction of a building called 'Majcin Dom' in their neighborhood and demanded the resignation of their mayor for the bad decision.
On Oct. 19, 2018: The Macedonian parliament voted in favor of renaming the state North Macedonia, thus aiming to end a long dispute with Greece and pave the way to NATO and EU membership.

On Nov. 17, 2018: Under the slogan 'Time for clean air', Skopje citizens protested in front of the Inspectorate of the City of Skopje demanding measures against air pollution. The demonstrators also criticized that the amount of 1.5 million euros projected to reduce air pollution was insufficient.

On Oct. 15, 2018: Employees from Sjekuricom protested in front of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia. They said they were dissatisfied with the unfulfilled promise that they would be paid their salaries for July, August and September.

On Oct. 5, 2018: Students protested in front of the Municipality of Bitola regarding the problems with the high fees they had to pay for public transportation and the old school facilities. The mayor of Bitola met with the students and promised improvements.
On Sept. 30, 2018: A man attacked three police officers in a school yard in Skopje during the referendum of voting the name of Macedonia. No injuries were reported.
On Sept. 27, 2018: Dozens of Macedonians protested in front of Parliament in Skopje to boycott the referendum for the name change of their country.
On Sept. 26, 2017: Employees from the factory Eurocomposit protested in front of the government in Skopje for their unpaid salaries and demanded severance pay.
Police Forces of North Macedonia (2017-) Prison Guards

On Sept. 24, 2018: Prison guards protested by blocking the junction with the Paloma Bianca shopping center in the center of Skopje with cars and motorcycles, asking the government to sign a collective agreeement regarding their work status.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On Sept. 16, 2018: Opposition party VMRO-DPMNE held a rally in Stip urging a crowd of about 2,000 people to reject the name change of Macedonia. Opposition leader Hristijan Mickoski told the crowd the government was 'taking advantage of the Macedonian people's strong will to achieve European standards, true prosperity, stability and security, to push an agenda that is against our state and national interests.'

On Sept. 16, 2018: Thousands of people led by Prime Minister Zaev staged a march for pro-European Macedonia that started near the Parliament and finished in front of the EU Delegation building in Skopje on the day of the name referendum, urging citizens to vote yes.

On Sept. 11, 2018: About 30 citizens protested in front of the Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts (MANU) in Skopje, where a scientific debate took place on the topic 'The Prespa Agreement: International Importance and Implications for the Euro-Atlantic Integration of the Republic of Macedonia.' The protesters were worried by threats to Macedonia's independence and called on Zaev's government to resign.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On Sept. 4, 2018: The opposition party VMRO-DPMNE organized a protest in Kicevo against the government and the name agreement, which according to VMRO was undermining the Macedonian national identity. The opposition also said the Prime Minister was not allowed to tell the citizens how to vote.

On August 7, 2018: Two citizens from Bitola attanded the Ilinden celebration in Krusevo and shouted offensive words along with the crowd towards state officials. The Prosecution office of Prilep filed criminal charged against them.

On July 27, 2018: Ecoactivists protested in Skopje with banners against construction on the Ohrid coast, placed in front of the municipal building where a Council meeting was held. The protesters declared their demands for a complete prohibition of coastal construction until proper planning documentation was adopted in accordance with a strategy for its sustainable development.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity
On July 16, 2018: The opposition party VMRO-DPMNE held a protest in Kavadarci, criticizing the incumbent government for failures in diplomacy, economy, healthcare, and education.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On July 8, 2018: Several thousand Macedonians held an anti-government protest in Skopje over economic policies and a deal with Greece to change the country's name to North Macedonia. The leader of the opposition party VMRO Hristijan Mickoski said that 'people are losing their country' due to the deal.

On July 5, 2018: Macedonia's parliament ratified a deal to change the former Yugoslav republic's name with neighboring Greece for the second time in two weeks, after the Macedonian president temporarily blocked the agreement.

On July 3, 2018: Employees at Eurocomposite from Prilep put tents in front of the Government building in Skopje, as part of the protest, demanding a final solution for the military equipment manufacturing plant and its unpaid debt and salaries.

On June 23, 2018: Thousands of Macedonians, organized by the student organization Youth for Macedonia, protested outside Macedonia's parliament building in Skopje against the deal with Greece aimed at ending a decade-long dispute over Macedonia's name. The protest was peaceful.

On June 19, 2018: The Macedonian parliament ratified the deal with Greece that solves the 27-year name dispute between the two states. The new name of the country -Republic of North Macedonia, would be used internationally and domestically. The new name is intended to distinguish the country now called Macedonia from a province in northern Greece that has the same name

On June 19, 2018: A dozen of protesters demonstrated outside the Macedonian parliament, where the ratification of the deal with Greece that solves the name dispute took place, dissatisfied with the new name of their country.
SDSM: Social Democratic Union of Macedonia; Government of North Macedonia (2017-)

On June 18, 2018: Police reported that unknown arsonists in Skopje set fire overnight to the car of a lawmaker from the left-wing governing party, who had attended Sunday's signing ceremony of the name deal between Macedonia and Greece.

On June 18, 2018: Around 50 demonstrators against the Macedonia name deal headed towards Macedonia square in Skopje and broke into two catering facilities, where they destroyed parts of the inventory. The demonstrators caused fear among the guests and used tear gas in one of the catering companies. They also set a van on fire in the vicinity of the Holiday Inn hotel in Skopje. No injuries were reported.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity
On June 17, 2018: Macedonia's main opposition party VMRO-DPMNE organized a protest in the city of Bitola against the name change of Macedonia. Around 5,000 people attended the rally.

On June 17, 2018: Demonstrators opposed to the name deal between Greece and Macedonia tried to push their way into the parliament building in Skopje. Police used tear gas to stop the demonstrators as they threw stones and firecrackers. Seven policemen were injured and 25 rioters detained late in the evening.

On June 16, 2018: Several citizens protested against the agreement with Greece and set up barricades of cartons and boxes outside the Parliament in Skopje. Police was present and no violence was reported.
On June 15, 2018: Macedonian citizens and civic association protested outside the Macedonian parliament in Skopje against the name deal reached between Macedonia and Greece.
VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On June 2, 2018: Thousands of Macedonians protested outside the main government building in Skopje to demand snap elections and reject a compromise solution with Greece over the Macedonia's name. The conservative VMRO-DPMNE party organized the march.

On May 23, 2018: Former Macedonian prime minister Nikola Gruevskiwas sentenced for two years in prison for acquiring personal gain and aiding a crime. Outside the court in Skopje, a group of his supporters protested his conviction.
On May 19, 2018: A small group of Macedonian protested outside a leaders' meeting venue in Skopje against the negotiations to change the name of Macedonia.
On May 13, 2018: Seamstresses from the Macedonia Garment Industry demonstrated demanding their overtime payments which they had not received for the past two months.

On May 5, 2018: Citizens and trade unions protested in front of the government in Skopje, demanding higher salaries , better general collective agreements in the public and private sector, and safe jobs.
Government of North Macedonia (2017-); Civilians (North Macedonia); Journalists (North Macedonia); Albanian Ethnic Group (North Macedonia)

On Apr. 27, 2018: Around 200 demonstrators stormed the parliament building in Skopje after an ethnic Albanian MP Xhaferi was elected speaker. They threw chairs and punches at journalists and MPs, injuring many people. Police deployed stun grenades to break up the demonstrators.

On Apr. 26, 2018: Hundreds of citizens protested in front of the Criminal Court in Skopje asking for justice for the Smilkovsko Lake case, which involved the murder of two boys. The protesters demanded responsibility from the judiciary and said victims would never be forgotten.

On Apr. 25, 2018: Hundreds of people gathered in front of the Parliament to protest against alienation from their children due to divorce or other circumstances and marked the World Day Against Parental Displacement.

On Apr. 22, 2018: Citizens from almost all villages in Debarna municipality blocked the traffic on the Ohrid-Kicevo road near the village of Botun. They protested against the construction of a landfill in their municipality, saying that it was an environmentally clean and unpolluted environment.

On Apr. 20, 2018: Employees of Prilep-based specialty 'Eurokomposit' plant blocked the Prilep-Gradsko road at the exit from Prilep for three and a half hours, protesting for the second day against not receiving their salaries from Eurokomposit.

On Apr. 19, 2018: Citizens protested in front of the Parliament in Skopje against the Almir case, a child who was killed by a car. The protesters were dissatisfied with the outcome of the case and seeking justice.

On Apr. 19, 2018: Employees of Prilep-based specialty 'Eurokomposit' plant blocked the Prilep-Gradsko road at the exit from Prilep for three and a half hours, protesting against not receiving their salaries from Eurokomposit.

On Apr. 5, 2018: A member of Macedonia's ruling ethnic Albanian party DUI, Naim Rexhepi, was shot dead during a fight with another party member in the village of Mala Recica near the western town of Tetovo. The shooting took place in the headquarters of DUI and the other part member was hospitalized. Presumably, the shooting came as a result of an internal fight for power

On Apr. 4, 2018: Citizens together with members of United for Macedonia gathered in a protest front of the Russian Embassy in Skopje to support an expelled Russian diplomat. The leader of United for Macedonia addressed the Russian embassador, stating that Macedonian people did not want to join the EU and NATO, but they had interest in the Eurasian Union.
On Mar. 29, 2018: Ethnic Macedonian group protested before Russian embassy in Skopje over an expelled Russian diplomat.

On Mar. 23, 2018: Macedonian citizens protested in front of the foreign ministry in Skopje during the visit of the Greek foreign minister Kotzias to show their discontent with the plans to change their country's name.

On Mar. 21, 2018: A group of ethnic Albanians protested in Kumanovo against the prosecution's decision to release an ethnic Macedonian who caused the death of a four-year-old ethnic Albanian child two years ago.

On Mar. 21, 2018: About 1,000 people protested in front of the government buildings and the Criminal Court in Skopje against the prosecution's decision to release a man who caused the death of a four-year-old child two years ago.
SDSM: Social Democratic Union of Macedonia

On Mar. 20, 2018: Ethnic Macedonians demonstrated in Skopje against the language law recognizing Albanian as an official language. The demonstration was accompanied by violent actions and damage to cars, the doors and windows of houses belonging to the Social Democratic Union of Macedonia.

On Mar. 18, 2018: Citizens gathered in front of the government in Skopje to protest against the law on languages, adopted by the Parliament on 14 March, which boosted the Albanian language status in Macedonia.

On Mar. 14, 2018: A few hundred protestors demonstrated outside the Parliament in Skopje against the newly adopted law bolstering the official use of the Albanian language in Macedonia. No incidents occurred.
On Mar. 4, 2018: Thousands of Macedonians protested a possible change to their country's name to comply with a demand by Greece at the main square in Skopje, chanting 'We are Macedonians.'
Macedonian Information Agency; AFP; Local Source; EuroNews

On Feb. 27, 2018: The World Macedonian Congress staged a demonstration outside the EU delegation in central Skopje against Macedonia's name change. Rioters threw rocks at the building and one police officer was injured. The demonstration continued outside the Parliament, where police found five bottles containing flammable liquid.
On Feb. 1, 2018: About 200 Macedonians protested during a UN visit in Skopje against peace talks intended to resolve the Macedonian name issue.

On Jan. 27, 2018: Macedonians protested against Prime Minister Zaev's proposal to rename Macedonia's main highway and airport, both named after Alexander the Great, and demanded name issue negotiations to be stopped.
On Jan. 26, 2018: Hundreds of Macedonias protested in Skopje to reexamine the charges in a case on the death of four-year-old ethnic Albanian two years ago.
Hardcore; VMRO-DPMNE: Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity

On January 21, hundreds of people gathered in front of the parliament in the capital Skopje to protest a bill that would make Albanian the country's second official language. The protest was organised by the groups Macedonian Unity Force and Hardcore [Tvrdokorni]. The protesters argued bilingualism would diminish Macedonia's unified character and burned an EU flag. Reports say the protest did not involve violence.
On Jan. 18, 2018: About a hundred Macedonians protested in Skopje against Macedonia's NATO accession and burned an alliance flag.

On Jan. 15, 2018: Macedonia ratified a friendship pact with Bulgaria aiming to end old ethnic and territorial disputes. Both countries have renounced territorial claims against each other, and Bulgaria has committed to support Macedonia in its efforts to join the European Union and NATO.
